Johann Sebastian Bach.passage: Johann Sebastian Bach (/ˈbɑːk/, /bæk/; German: [ˈɡoːfʁɔnt ˈseːbəɐnt ˈbax]; 21 March 1685 – 28 July 1750) was a German composer and musician of the Baroque period. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest composers of all time. Bach's prolific and wide-ranging output comprises more than 6,000 compositions, including sacred and secular vocal music, choral and orchestral works, and works for solo violin and solo keyboard. Bach wrote both sacred and secular music, including many of the standards of the German and international repertories. He was a proficient player of the viola da gamba, recorder, violin, and clavier (harpsichord), and was an important figure in the development of the piano. His music integrates elements from different musical traditions of his time, including Italian opera and French dance music. He was also greatly admired during his lifetime, and was one of the most influential musicians of the 18th century. The majority of Bach's music is published in standardized editions, making it readily available to performers and audiences today. Bach's influence on music is pervasive and transcends genres; Johann Strauss II's Waltz in A Flat Major is one of his most famous musical descendants.

qae_pairs.question: When did Johann Sebastian Bach die?
qae_pairs.explanation: Johann Sebastian Bach died on 28 July 1750.

qae_pairs.question: When was Johann Sebastian Bach born?
qae_pairs.explanation: Johann Sebastian Bach was born on 21 March 1685.

Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.passage: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart ( ; 27 January 1756 -- 5 December 1791) was an Austrian composer and pianist of the Classical era. He composed mainly for the piano, but also wrote a significant amount of symphonies, concertos, operas, and chamber music. He is widely considered one of the greatest and most influential musicians of all time.

Ludwig van Beethoven.passage: Ludwig van Beethoven (German: [ˈlʊdv̩tˌbɛθfən]; 1770–1827), nicknamed LvB, was a German composer and pianist who is widely regarded as a pivotal figure in the development of Western art music. He was born in Bonn into a musically active family of teachers; his father was a court musician, and his younger brothers became professional musicians as well. At an early age, he displayed a talent for music that was evident even to his teachers, and his father arranged for him to study with Antonio Salieri, the foremost composer in Vienna. Salieri recognized Beethoven's talent and dedicated his time to teaching the boy, hoping to make a professional musician out of him. In Vienna, the 17-year-old Beethoven was exposed to the music of Johann Sebastian Bach and Georg Philipp Telemann, and he began to compose his own music. He was profoundly influenced by Johann Sebastian Bach, whose music he came to regard as the pinnacle of perfection. In 1792, Beethoven's father died suddenly and his financial support ended. He was forced to leave Vienna, and he began a period of wandering during which he composed some of his best-known works, including the "Appassionata" and "Waldhorn" piano sonatas and the "Missa Solemnis".

Joseph Haydn.passage: Joseph Haydn (1732–1809) was an Austrian composer and a prominent member of the Classical period. He is regarded as one of the most important composers in the Western classical tradition, alongside such figures as Mozart and Beethoven. Haydn was born in Rohrau, Lower Austria, to a large and musically talented family. He began his career as a child prodigy, touring throughout Europe with his brother Michael as keyboard players with the orchestra at the Viennese court. In 1759, he married Anna Maria Rosalia Bianca, the niece of his first employer, and settled in Vienna. There Haydn composed prolifically, and by 1790 was recognized as one of the most important composers of his time. He was appointed as the court composer for the Habsburg monarchy and composed many works in the service of the nobility. His most celebrated period was from 1790 to 1805, when he composed his oratorios and operas. He died in Vienna at the age of 77. Haydn's music covers a broad stylistic range. In his early years, he wrote mainly divertimentos, including symphonies, chamber music, and piano sonatas. In his middle years, he began to write more serious music in the form of string quartets, symphonies, and other large-scale forms.

Franz Schubert.passage: Franz Schubert (31 January 1797 – 19 November 1828) was a prolific Austrian composer. He is among the best-known and most influential of the classical era. He is also among the most frequently performed of the classical composers, and is frequently featured in classical radio and television programming. Schubert composed over 1000 works, including lieder, choral works, symphonies, piano sonatas, and a large body of instrumental music. He wrote most of his output between 1814 and his early death at age 31, but he continued to compose and revise up until a month before his death, and some of his later works have been shown to be substantially complete as early as 1822, when Schubert was only 17. Schubert's music is notable for its grace and beauty, and for its use of traditional musical forms. He was a child prodigy, able to play a wide variety of musical instruments, but he did not begin composing seriously until his late teenage years, and he did not begin to take piano lessons until he was 12. He composed prolifically throughout his short life, and he composed some of his works in a wide range of musical forms, including opera, art songs, sonatas, symphonies, masses, and choral music. Schubert's music is admired for its gentle lyricism and melodic gift, as well as its contrapuntal skill and use of traditional forms.

Franz Liszt.passage: Franz Liszt (Hungarian: Ferenc Liszt, pronounced [ˈfɛ�ʁɛnt lɪʃts]; 25 September [1] 1811 – 29 September 1886) was a Hungarian composer, pianist, and conductor. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest and most prolific composers of piano music during the late Romantic era. His virtuosic piano works, which include many of the most popular pieces for the instrument, remain in high demand for concert performances, while his larger-scale works for solo piano, choral, and orchestra, including twelve symphonies, remain popular among concert-goers and recording audiences. Liszt was also an influential teacher who mentored many important composers, including Johannes Brahms, Richard Wagner, Bedřich Smetana, and Antonín Dvořák. Liszt was born in Raiding, Hungary, to a Hungarian mother and an Italian father, both of whom were teachers. He showed musical talent at a young age and began piano lessons with Carl Czerny at the age of five. At nine, he was sent to Vienna to continue his studies with Aloys Fürst, and at thirteen he entered the Royal Academy of Music, where one of his teachers was Johann Peter Pixis. He began composing from an early age, and by the age of fourteen had composed a full-scale opera.

Richard Wagner.passage: Richard Wagner (German: [ˈʁɪçk ˈvaɪɡn̩]; 7 May 1813 – 13 February 1883) was a German composer, theatre director, and polemicist. He is widely regarded as the greatest composer of opera in the German tradition. Wagner wrote more than twenty-four operas, of which the best known is Der Ring des Nibelungen (The Ring of the Nibelung). Wagner's music is notable for its development of Romantic music traditions, use of leitmotifs and pioneering use of music drama. His works are frequently performed in concert and in opera productions around the world, especially in Germany. Wagner was a prominent German nationalist who became an outspoken critic of democracy and liberalism, and of the policies of the German Chancellor Otto von Bismarck. He was also a devout Christian and a strong advocate of German nationalism, anti-semitism, and anti-communism. Wagner's prodigious musical and literary output has had a profound influence on composers, musicologists and philosophers, and his ideas about opera and art have been influential in the 20th and 21st centuries. Wagner was born into a family of actors and travelled widely during his childhood. He received early musical education in piano and violin and, from 1831, attended the University of Leipzig, where he studied theology.

Michael.passage: Michael Joseph Jackson (August 29, 1958 – June 25, 2009) was an American singer, songwriter, and dancer. He was a member of the Jackson family, the founder of the Jackson 5. Jackson was a pioneer of popular music and contemporary pop culture, and is often credited with popularizing the use of sequencers, synthesizers and digital music technology in mainstream music. He was also a major figure of 20th-century popular music and is often referred to as "the King of Pop". He was a figure of controversy and is considered one of the most significant cultural icons of the 20th century. Jackson's music and public performances incorporated themes of joy, love, and liberation, and he was noted for his eccentric and sometimes controversial behavior and stagecraft. He was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame twice. Jackson was the first artist to have two number-one albums on the Billboard 200 simultaneously, as well as the first to achieve eight number-one singles on the "Billboard" Hot 100. He was also the first artist to have a number one single on "Billboard"'s Hot 100 in five different decades. Jackson was the first artist to have a Top 40 hit on the Billboard Hot 100 dated from August 1969 to June 1970, a span of nearly five and a half years, and the first to have a number one single on the UK singles chart dated from March 1976 to November 1991, a span of nearly 26 years.

Inferno.passage: Inferno (Dante Alighieri) is a long narrative poem by Dante Alighieri, written in terza rima. Germany.passage: Germany (German: Deutschland [ɛ̃ˌʔltsaːn], listen), officially the Federal Republic of Germany (German: Bundesrepublik Deutschland [ˈbʊndɐʁʏlprəˌʔlʏtç ˈdʁiːʃtʁɛ̃pʊblik]), is a country in Central Europe. It includes 16 constituent states, covers an area of, and has a largely temperate seasonal climate. With about 82 million inhabitants, Germany is the most populous member state of the European Union. After the United States, it is the second-largest country in Europe. Germany's capital and largest metropolis is Berlin. Other major cities include Hamburg, Munich, Cologne, and Frankfurt. About a quarter of the population lives in urban areas, the most in any EU country. Germany's major export industries include machinery, vehicles, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and electrical equipment. Germany also has a strong automotive industry and is a global leader in aerospace. It also has one of the largest national railway systems in the world. The country has a very high standard of living and ranks third in the world in nominal GDP (gross domestic product) per capita, behind Qatar and Luxembourg.

the University of Leipzig.passage: The University of Leipzig, founded in 1409, is the second-oldest university in Germany, after the University of Heidelberg, and the oldest in Saxony. The University of Leipzig is a public research university in Leipzig, Saxony, Germany, with an enrollment of approximately 20,000 students and 3,600 faculty and academic staff. The university was founded in 1409 and is the second-oldest university in Germany, after the University of Heidelberg, and the oldest in Saxony.

qae_pairs.question: Which country is the University of Leipzig located in?
qae_pairs.explanation: The University of Leipzig is located in Leipzig, Saxony, Germany.

qae_pairs.question: What year was the University of Leipzig founded?
qae_pairs.explanation: The University of Leipzig was founded in 1409.

Oranienbaum.passage: Oranienbaum (Russian: Орани́ненба́м, tr. Oranienbaum, IPA: [ˈoˈraːnʲiːnˠbɐ̯m̩]; also transliterated Oranienburg) is a Russian town and a former summer residence of the tsars, located on the eastern shore of the Gulf of Finland in Leningrad Oblast, about 40 km (25 mi) south-east of St. Petersburg. It is a popular tourist destination, with the former imperial residences open to the public.

qae_pairs.question: What is the name of the body of water that is located near Oranienbaum?
qae_pairs.explanation: Oranienbaum is a Russian town and a former summer residence of the tsars, located on the eastern shore of the Gulf of Finland in Leningrad Oblast, about 40 km (25 mi) south-east of St. Petersburg.

Russian Empire.passage: The Tsardom of Russia (Russian: Росси́йская Ца́рдмоло́дь, tr. Russkaja tsardomloĭ), also known as the Russian Empire, was a state that existed from 1721, following the end of the Russo-Persian War of 1722–1723 and the Treaty of Georgievsk, until its dissolution in 1922. It was one of the largest empires in history, at its maximum reaching from the Baltic Sea in the north to the Pacific Ocean in the east, and from the North Atlantic Ocean in the west to Central and Eastern Europe and the Caucasus in the south. The Tsardom of Russia ("Russian Tsardom") was established after the dissolution of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth in the aftermath of the Polish-Russian-Swedish War. The Tsardom was originally a union of lands of the former Rus' principalities, with its capital in Moscow, that was established under the leadership of the House of Romanov.

qae_pairs.question: What year did the Russian Empire end?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Russian Empire ended in 1922.

qae_pairs.question: What is a question about the Russian Empire that contains the term 'the North Atlantic Ocean'?
qae_pairs.explanation: The North Atlantic Ocean was the largest empire in history, at its maximum reaching from the Baltic Sea in the north to the Pacific Ocean in the east, and from the North Atlantic Ocean in the west to Central and Eastern Europe and the Caucasus in the south.

Stravinsky.passage: Igor Stravinsky ( /ˈstrɑvɪnʃəs/;[nb 1] Russian: Игорь Стравинссы;[nb 2] Russian pronunciation: (ˈstravinsʲɪs); 25 October [O.S. 6 October] 1882 – 8 September 1971) was a Russian-born French composer of the late Romantic period, who exerted enormous influence on the development of music in the 20th century. Stravinsky was a pioneer of the music composition that came to be known as "neoclassicism". His works include ballets, concerti, film scores, and chamber music.

qae_pairs.question: What is the type of music that Igor Stravinsky composed?
qae_pairs.explanation: Igor Stravinsky composed concerti.

qae_pairs.question: What is the birth date of Igor Stravinsky?
qae_pairs.explanation: Igor Stravinsky (Russian: Игорь Стравинссы; 25 October [O.S. 6 October] 1882 – 8 September 1971) was a Russian-born French composer of the late Romantic period, who exerted enormous influence on the development of music in the 20th century. Stravinsky was a pioneer of the music composition that came to be known as neoclassicism.
